name: Optimize MCP: Inspect your n8n server tools

options.systemMessage:
You are a helpful assistant - funny and precise.

To introduce yourself, you give a short overview of your available tools.

If you get URLs (e.g. from tools), you provide them - best as clickable links.

parameters.description: Get the current date and time as an ISO 8601 string with milliseconds and timezone offset. This does not require any parameters. It's appropriate to deliver a fast answer.

parameters.content:
### Code Tool
Returns the current date and time as configured in your n8n server.
(If an agent calls this tool, it may come up with a additional incorrect weekday.)

### Call n8n Workflow Tool
This tool requires a timeZone (e.g. "Europe/Berlin") and a locale (e.g. "en-US"). It returns a string with complete time information (e.g. "Saturday, 2025-11-22 15:30:00 (Europe/Berlin)")

### AI Agent Tool
AI agent (LLM with tool), which is able to access the current Wikipedia data.

Tech insights: This n8n (v.1.120.4) node uses [langchain](https://github.com/n8n-io/n8n/blob/patch/1.120.4/pnpm-lock.yaml#L12) (v.0.3.50) and runs a [Wikipedia query](https://github.com/n8n-io/n8n/blob/patch/1.120.4/packages/%40n8n/nodes-langchain/nodes/tools/ToolWikipedia/ToolWikipedia.node.ts#L1C37-L1C82), which calls the [Wikipedia (en) API](https://github.com/langchain-ai/langchainjs/blob/%40langchain/core%3D%3D0.3.50/libs/langchain-community/src/tools/wikipedia_query_run.ts#L135) with the property [extracts](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/api.php?action=help&modules=query%2Bextracts).

parameters.toolDescription: Call this tool to get an expert opinion relating general topics. Ask for a topic like you would search in Wikipedia. This expert tool can look up in the current Wikipedia. After getting an answer, check, if the provided data relates to your initial request/task.

options.systemMessage:
You are an expert, a polymath. You can access the knowledge of the entire current Wikipedia (only requests in English).
If you can make up a guess of a good Wikipedia search term/title/query, first consult Wikipedia and use it for your response.
You respond precisely, briefly, and truthfully.
If you cannot provide an answer with at least 80% confidence, respond with a generalized perspective.

parameters.description:
Gets the formatted datetime string showing e.g. ISO-style date, 24-hour time, and timezone.
Format: dddd, YYYY-MM-DD HH:mm:ss (TIMEZONE).
Parameters values should be known to ensure correct formatting.
Example values are:
timeZone: "Europe/Berlin"
locale: "en-US"

workflowId.cachedResultName: Optimize MCP: Inspect your n8n server tools

parameters.toolDescription: Get an recent news and updates of n8n. The result is returned in XML/RSS format.

parameters.content:
## Part 1: MCP Server
This is your MCP server setup. Agents (LLMs with MCP and tool support) will be able use your provided tools.

## Part 2: AI Agent Chat (Using the MCP server)
Have a chat with a LLM model, which is connected to your MCP server.

## Part 3: Inspect Your MCP Setup

Inspect the interface accassible by LLMs. Most interesting is tools/list. Also check Server-Sent Events (SSE) and [GitHub](https://github.com/adibaba/n8n.workflows) for additional optimizations.

For setup:
Set a chat model

For setup:
Set a chat model

For setup: 
Set MCP Production URL

For setup: 
Set MCP Production URL

## Optimize Your MCP Server in n8n
### How it works
This is a n8n, LLM and MCP poweruser workflow. It is designed to inspect and improve MCP server components. This workflow consists of 4 parts:
1. **Set up** a **MCP Server**. In this workflow, a template is provided with common n8n tools: *Code Tool*, *Call n8n Workflow Tool*, *HTTP Request Too*l and *AI Agent Tool*.
These tools are chosen for multiple optimization and data of a maybe older LLM. Such a LLM is maybe not aware of: the current time, n8n updates or facts added to current Wikipedia. Let's provide that by MCP tools!
2. **Use** the **AI Agent Chat** to test your MCP server. You can use the *Open chat* button and write a message. Ask for something related to the current time (and weekday), n8n updates or a general topic. Your LLM will be able to get current news based on your MCP server.
3.  **Inspect** the **Model Context Protocol (MCP)** endpoint for further optimizations. It provides information a LLM connected to your MCP server would also see. What's the best description? Which methods would probably be called? For technical details, visit [modelcontextprotocol.io](https://modelcontextprotocol.io/) and [GitHub](https://github.com/adibaba/n8n.workflows).
4. **Optimize** the **MCP Server Tools**. First, verify that each tool’s JSON matches the provided JSON Schema. Then check the tools against best practices.

### Setup steps
- (In general:) The **nodes to be updated** are **highlighted by sticky notes**.
- In part 1, "**Call n8n Workflow Tool**", select this (the current) workflow.
- Copy the **Production URL** from **MCP Server Trigger** in part 1. 
  - In part 2, and the **MCP Client** node, set your MCP server *Production URL*. 
  - In part 3, and **mcpEndpoint** node, also insert the *Production URL* of your MCP server.
- Set a **Chat Model** for each, the ***AI Agent TOOL*** (in part 1) and the ***AI Agent Chat*** (in part 2) and the ***final LLM calls*** (in part 4). 
You could also use the same model and credentials for all. In this workflow, models with a free plan are included. See **n8n Credential Docs** for [Mistral](https://docs.n8n.io/integrations/builtin/credentials/mistral/) and [Google](https://docs.n8n.io/integrations/builtin/credentials/google/).
- Activate this workflow.

### Inspect & Optimize
Check the **n8n executions** (and called tools) for chat messages like:
- What is the current time?
- What is the current weekday?
- What time is it in Sydney?
- What's new in n8n?
- What is Model Context Protocol (MCP)?

Finally: Maybe add a description for missing parameters.

### Customization
- Edit one of the four MCP server tools.
- Deactivate some of the MCP server tools.
- Add MCP server tools to be inspected
- Edit the AI Agent (node "expert") system message.
- Check the changes in the final MCP setup part, also check n8n executions.
For setup: Get MCP Production URL

### HTTP Request Tool
Returns current articles of the n8n blog in RSS/Atom format.

## Part 4: Optimize your tools

Use this part to check for limitations of your current MCP tool list setup. The used prompt are specified according MCP Schema 2024-11-05. Later versions may require additional changes.
If you'lL get a message stating the 'expert' tool is missing a required 'description': You can fix it.

parameters.text:
=Check if the JSON conforms to the following best practices:

ToolsArray Schema Checklist

1. Tool Name
   - Must exist (`name` is required).
   - Should be descriptive and human-friendly.
   - Avoid vague or overlapping names.

2. Tool Description
   - Must exist (`description` property).
   - Clearly describe what the tool does.

3. Input Schema
   - `inputSchema.type` must be "object".
   - `inputSchema.properties` should list all input parameters.
   - Each parameter should have:
     - A description (`description`)
     - Clear indication if it is required (via `inputSchema.required`)
     - Optional parameters should include default value if applicable

4. Required Fields
   - Every tool object must at least have `name` and `inputSchema` as per schema.

5. Additional Properties
   - Parameters may allow `additionalProperties` if flexibility is needed.

Be gentle, some of the best practices rely on a future version of the JSON Schema provided below.
- A missing parameter description is a fail.
- Double underscores or trailing underscores are okay.

Return your results according to the attached JSON Schema.

# JSON

{{ JSON.stringify($json.toolsList) }}

# JSON Schema

{
  "$schema": "http://json-schema.org/draft-07/schema#",
  "title": "ToolsArray",
  "type": "array",
  "description": "An array of tools available to the client.",
  "author": "Adrian Wilke",
  "basedOn": "MCP Schema 2024-11-05",
  "items": {
    "type": "object",
    "description": "Definition for a tool the client can call.",
    "properties": {
      "name": {
        "type": "string",
        "description": "The name of the tool."
      },
      "description": {
        "type": "string",
        "description": "A human-readable description of the tool."
      },
      "inputSchema": {
        "type": "object",
        "description": "A JSON Schema object defining the expected parameters for the tool.",
        "properties": {
          "type": { "const": "object", "type": "string" },
          "properties": { "type": "object", "additionalProperties": true },
          "required": { "type": "array", "items": { "type": "string" } },
          "additionalProperties": { "type": "boolean" }
        },
        "required": ["type"],
        "additionalProperties": true
      }
    },
    "required": ["name", "inputSchema"]
  }
}
